commands.name: help
commands.description: Displays help for a command
commands.help:
The <info>help</info> command displays help for a given command:

  <info>php /index.php help list</info>

You can also output the help in other formats by using the <comment>--format</comment> option:

  <info>php /index.php help --format=xml list</info>

To display the list of available commands, please use the <info>list</info> command.

format.name: --format
format.description: To output help in other formats

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: list
commands.description: Lists commands
commands.help:
The <info>list</info> command lists all commands:

  <info>php /index.php list</info>

You can also display the commands for a specific namespace:

  <info>php /index.php list test</info>

You can also output the information in other formats by using the <comment>--format</comment> option:

  <info>php /index.php list --format=xml</info>

It's also possible to get raw list of commands (useful for embedding command runner):

  <info>php /index.php list --raw</info>

format.name: --format
format.description: To output list in other formats

commands.name: acme:hello
commands.description: Hello World example command
commands.help:
The <info>acme:hello</info> command greets somebody or everybody:

<info>php /index.php acme:hello</info>

The optional argument specifies who to greet:

<info>php /index.php acme:hello</info> Fabien

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

period.description: Set the polling period in seconds (used with --watch)

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation

commands.name: assets:install
commands.description: Installs bundles web assets under a public web directory
commands.help:
The <info>assets:install</info> command installs bundle assets into a given
directory (e.g. the web directory).

<info>php /index.php assets:install web</info>

A "bundles" directory will be created inside the target directory, and the
"Resources/public" directory of each bundle will be copied into it.

To create a symlink to each bundle instead of copying its assets, use the
<info>--symlink</info> option:

<info>php /index.php assets:install web --symlink</info>

To make symlink relative, add the <info>--relative</info> option:

<info>php /index.php assets:install web --symlink --relative</info>

symlink.name: --symlink
symlink.description: Symlinks the assets instead of copying it

commands.name: cache:clear
commands.description: Clears the cache
commands.help:
The <info>cache:clear</info> command clears the application cache for a given environment
and debug mode:

<info>php /index.php cache:clear --env=dev</info>
<info>php /index.php cache:clear --env=prod --no-debug</info>

no-warmup.name: --no-warmup
no-warmup.description: Do not warm up the cache

commands.name: cache:warmup
commands.description: Warms up an empty cache
commands.help:
The <info>cache:warmup</info> command warms up the cache.

Before running this command, the cache must be empty.

This command does not generate the classes cache (as when executing this
command, too many classes that should be part of the cache are already loaded
in memory). Use <comment>curl</comment> or any other similar tool to warm up
the classes cache if you want.

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: config:dump-reference
commands.description: Dumps the default configuration for an extension
commands.help:
The <info>config:dump-reference</info> command dumps the default configuration for an
extension/bundle.

The extension alias or bundle name can be used:

  <info>php /index.php config:dump-reference framework</info>
  <info>php /index.php config:dump-reference FrameworkBundle</info>

With the <info>format</info> option specifies the format of the configuration,
this is either <comment>yaml</comment> or <comment>xml</comment>. When the option is not provided, <comment>yaml</comment> is used.

name.name: name
name.description: The Bundle name or the extension alias

format.name: --format
format.description: The format, either yaml or xml

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: container:debug
commands.description: Displays current services for an application
commands.help:
The <info>container:debug</info> command displays all configured <comment>public</comment> services:

  <info>php /index.php container:debug</info>

To get specific information about a service, specify its name:

  <info>php /index.php container:debug validator</info>

By default, private services are hidden. You can display all services by
using the --show-private flag:

  <info>php /index.php container:debug --show-private</info>

Use the --tags option to display tagged <comment>public</comment> services grouped by tag:

  <info>php /index.php container:debug --tags</info>

Find all services with a specific tag by specifying the tag name with the --tag option:

  <info>php /index.php container:debug --tag=form.type</info>

Use the --parameters option to display all parameters:

  <info>php /index.php container:debug --parameters</info>

Display a specific parameter by specifying his name with the --parameter option:

  <info>php /index.php container:debug --parameter=kernel.debug</info>

show-private.name: --show-private
show-private.description: Use to show public *and* private services

tag.name: --tag
tag.description: Show all services with a specific tag

tags.name: --tags
tags.description: Displays tagged services for an application

parameter.name: --parameter
parameter.description: Displays a specific parameter for an application

format.description: To output description in other formats

commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:cache:clear-metadata</info> command clears all metadata
cache for the default entity manager:

<info>php app/console doctrine:cache:clear-metadata</info>

You can also optionally specify the <comment>--em</comment> option to specify
which entity manager to clear the cache for:

<info>php app/console doctrine:cache:clear-metadata --em=default</info>

commands.name: doctrine:database:create
commands.description: Creates the configured databases
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:database:create</info> command creates the default
connections database:

<info>php app/console doctrine:database:create</info>

You can also optionally specify the name of a connection to create the
database for:

<info>php app/console doctrine:database:create --connection=default</info>

commands.name: doctrine:database:drop
commands.description: Drops the configured databases
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:database:drop</info> command drops the default connections
database:

<info>php app/console doctrine:database:drop</info>

The --force parameter has to be used to actually drop the database.

You can also optionally specify the name of a connection to drop the database
for:

<info>php app/console doctrine:database:drop --connection=default</info>

<error>Be careful: All data in a given database will be lost when executing
this command.</error>

commands.name: doctrine:ensure-production-settings
commands.description: Verify that Doctrine is properly configured for a production environment.
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:ensure-production-settings</info> command ensures that
Doctrine is properly configured for a production environment.:

<info>php app/console doctrine:ensure-production-settings</info>

You can also optionally specify the <comment>--em</comment> option to specify
which entity manager to use:

<info>php app/console doctrine:ensure-production-settings --em=default</info>

commands.name: doctrine:generate:crud
commands.description: Generates a CRUD based on a Doctrine entity
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:generate:crud</info> command generates a CRUD based on a Doctrine entity.

The default command only generates the list and show actions.

<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:crud --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Post --route-prefix=post_admin</info>

Using the --with-write option allows to generate the new, edit and delete actions.

<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:crud --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Post --route-prefix=post_admin --with-write</info>

Every generated file is based on a template. There are default templates but they can be overriden by placing custom templates in one of the following locations, by order of priority:

<info>BUNDLE_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/crud
APP_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/crud</info>

And

<info>__bundle_path__/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/form
__project_root__/app/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/form</info>

You can check https://github.com/sensio/SensioGeneratorBundle/tree/master/Resources/skeleton
in order to know the file structure of the skeleton

entity.name: --entity
entity.description: The entity class name to initialize (shortcut notation)

with-write.name: --with-write
with-write.description: Whether or not to generate create, new and delete actions

format.name: --format
format.description: Use the format for configuration files (php, xml, yml, or annotation)

overwrite.name: --overwrite
overwrite.description: Do not stop the generation if crud controller already exist, thus overwriting all generated files

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: doctrine:generate:entities
commands.description: Generates entity classes and method stubs from your mapping information
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:generate:entities</info> command generates entity classes
and method stubs from your mapping information:

You have to limit generation of entities:

* To a bundle:

  <info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities MyCustomBundle</info>

* To a single entity:

  <info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities MyCustomBundle:User</info>
  <info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities MyCustomBundle/Entity/User</info>

* To a namespace

  <info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities MyCustomBundle/Entity</info>

If the entities are not stored in a bundle, and if the classes do not exist,
the command has no way to guess where they should be generated. In this case,
you must provide the <comment>--path</comment> option:

  <info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities Blog/Entity --path=src/</info>

By default, the unmodified version of each entity is backed up and saved
(e.g. Product.php~). To prevent this task from creating the backup file,
pass the <comment>--no-backup</comment> option:

  <info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities Blog/Entity --no-backup</info>

<error>Important:</error> Even if you specified Inheritance options in your
XML or YAML Mapping files the generator cannot generate the base and
child classes for you correctly, because it doesn't know which
class is supposed to extend which. You have to adjust the entity
code manually for inheritance to work!

name.name: name
name.description: A bundle name, a namespace, or a class name

path.name: --path
path.description: The path where to generate entities when it cannot be guessed

no-backup.name: --no-backup
no-backup.description: Do not backup existing entities files.

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: doctrine:generate:entity
commands.description: Generates a new Doctrine entity inside a bundle
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:generate:entity</info> task generates a new Doctrine
entity inside a bundle:

<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post</info>

The above command would initialize a new entity in the following entity
namespace <info>Acme\BlogBundle\Entity\Blog\Post</info>.

You can also optionally specify the fields you want to generate in the new
entity:

<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post --fields="title:string(255) body:text"</info>

The command can also generate the corresponding entity repository class with the
<comment>--with-repository</comment> option:

<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post --with-repository</info>

By default, the command uses annotations for the mapping information; change it
with <comment>--format</comment>:

<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post --format=yml</info>

To deactivate the interaction mode, simply use the `--no-interaction` option
without forgetting to pass all needed options:

<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post --format=annotation --fields="title:string(255) body:text" --with-repository --no-interaction</info>

entity.name: --entity
entity.description: The entity class name to initialize (shortcut notation)

fields.name: --fields
fields.description: The fields to create with the new entity

format.name: --format
format.description: Use the format for configuration files (php, xml, yml, or annotation)

with-repository.name: --with-repository
with-repository.description: Whether to generate the entity repository or not

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: doctrine:generate:form
commands.description: Generates a form type class based on a Doctrine entity
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:generate:form</info> command generates a form class based on a Doctrine entity.

<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:form AcmeBlogBundle:Post</info>

Every generated file is based on a template. There are default templates but they can be overriden by placing custom templates in one of the following locations, by order of priority:

<info>BUNDLE_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/form
APP_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/form</info>

You can check https://github.com/sensio/SensioGeneratorBundle/tree/master/Resources/skeleton
in order to know the file structure of the skeleton

commands.description: Convert mapping information between supported formats.
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:mapping:convert</info> command converts mapping information
between supported formats:

<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:convert xml /path/to/output</info>

commands.name: doctrine:mapping:import
commands.description: Imports mapping information from an existing database
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:mapping:import</info> command imports mapping information
from an existing database:

<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml</info>

You can also optionally specify which entity manager to import from with the
<info>--em</info> option:

<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml --em=default</info>

If you don't want to map every entity that can be found in the database, use the
<info>--filter</info> option. It will try to match the targeted mapped entity with the
provided pattern string.

<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml --filter=MyMatchedEntity</info>

Use the <info>--force</info> option, if you want to override existing mapping files:

<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml --force</info>

bundle.name: bundle
bundle.description: The bundle to import the mapping information to

mapping-type.name: mapping-type
mapping-type.description: The mapping type to export the imported mapping information to

em.name: --em
em.description: The entity manager to use for this command

filter.name: --filter
filter.description: A string pattern used to match entities that should be mapped.

force.name: --force
force.description: Force to overwrite existing mapping files.

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

commands.name: doctrine:mapping:info
commands.description: Shows basic information about all mapped entities
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:mapping:info</info> shows basic information about which
entities exist and possibly if their mapping information contains errors or
not.

<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:info</info>

If you are using multiple entity managers you can pick your choice with the
<info>--em</info> option:

<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:info --em=default</info>

commands.name: doctrine:query:dql
commands.description: Executes arbitrary DQL directly from the command line.
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:query:dql</info> command executes the given DQL query and
outputs the results:

<info>php app/console doctrine:query:dql "SELECT u FROM UserBundle:User u"</info>

You can also optional specify some additional options like what type of
hydration to use when executing the query:

<info>php app/console doctrine:query:dql "SELECT u FROM UserBundle:User u" --hydrate=array</info>

Additionally you can specify the first result and maximum amount of results to
show:

<info>php app/console doctrine:query:dql "SELECT u FROM UserBundle:User u" --first-result=0 --max-result=30</info>

hydrate.name: --hydrate
hydrate.description: Hydration mode of result set. Should be either: object, array, scalar or single-scalar.

first-result.name: --first-result
first-result.description: The first result in the result set.

max-result.name: --max-result
max-result.description: The maximum number of results in the result set.

em.name: --em
em.description: The entity manager to use for this command

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: doctrine:query:sql
commands.description: Executes arbitrary SQL directly from the command line.
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:query:sql</info> command executes the given SQL query and
outputs the results:

<info>php app/console doctrine:query:sql "SELECT * from user"</info>

connection.name: --connection
connection.description: The connection to use for this command

verbose.name: --verbose

no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: doctrine:schema:create
commands.description: Executes (or dumps) the SQL needed to generate the database schema
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:schema:create</info> command executes the SQL needed to
generate the database schema for the default entity manager:

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:create</info>

You can also generate the database schema for a specific entity manager:

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:create --em=default</info>

Finally, instead of executing the SQL, you can output the SQL:

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:create --dump-sql</info>

dump-sql.name: --dump-sql
dump-sql.description: Instead of try to apply generated SQLs into EntityManager Storage Connection, output them.

em.name: --em
em.description: The entity manager to use for this command

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: doctrine:schema:drop
commands.description: Executes (or dumps) the SQL needed to drop the current database schema
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:schema:drop</info> command generates the SQL needed to
drop the database schema of the default entity manager:

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:drop --dump-sql</info>

Alternatively, you can execute the generated queries:

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:drop --force</info>

You can also optionally specify the name of a entity manager to drop the
schema for:

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:drop --em=default</info>

dump-sql.name: --dump-sql
dump-sql.description: Instead of try to apply generated SQLs into EntityManager Storage Connection, output them.

force.name: --force
force.description: Don't ask for the deletion of the database, but force the operation to run.

full-database.name: --full-database
full-database.description: Instead of using the Class Metadata to detect the database table schema, drop ALL assets that the database contains.

em.name: --em
em.description: The entity manager to use for this command

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: doctrine:schema:update
commands.description: Executes (or dumps) the SQL needed to update the database schema to match the current mapping metadata
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:schema:update</info> command generates the SQL needed to
synchronize the database schema with the current mapping metadata of the
default entity manager.

For example, if you add metadata for a new column to an entity, this command
would generate and output the SQL needed to add the new column to the database:

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:update --dump-sql</info>

Alternatively, you can execute the generated queries:

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:update --force</info>

You can also update the database schema for a specific entity manager:

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:update --em=default</info>

complete.name: --complete
complete.description: If defined, all assets of the database which are not relevant to the current metadata will be dropped.

dump-sql.name: --dump-sql
dump-sql.description: Dumps the generated SQL statements to the screen (does not execute them).

force.name: --force
force.description: Causes the generated SQL statements to be physically executed against your database.

em.name: --em
em.description: The entity manager to use for this command

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: doctrine:schema:validate
commands.description: Validates the doctrine mapping files
commands.help:
The <info>doctrine:schema:validate</info> checks the current mappings
for valid forward and reverse mappings.

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:validate</info>

You can also optionally specify the <comment>--em</comment> option to specify
which entity manager use for the validation.

<info>php app/console doctrine:schema:validate --em=default</info>

em.name: --em
em.description: The entity manager to use for this command

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: generate:bundle
commands.description: Generates a bundle
commands.help:
The <info>generate:bundle</info> command helps you generates new bundles.

By default, the command interacts with the developer to tweak the generation.
Any passed option will be used as a default value for the interaction
(<comment>--namespace</comment> is the only one needed if you follow the
conventions):

<info>php app/console generate:bundle --namespace=Acme/BlogBundle</info>

Note that you can use <comment>/</comment> instead of <comment>\ </comment>for the namespace delimiter to avoid any
problem.

If you want to disable any user interaction, use <comment>--no-interaction</comment> but don't forget to pass all needed options:

<info>php app/console generate:bundle --namespace=Acme/BlogBundle --dir=src [--bundle-name=...] --no-interaction</info>

Note that the bundle namespace must end with "Bundle".

namespace.name: --namespace
namespace.description: The namespace of the bundle to create

dir.name: --dir
dir.description: The directory where to create the bundle

format.name: --format
format.description: Use the format for configuration files (php, xml, yml, or annotation)

structure.name: --structure
structure.description: Whether to generate the whole directory structure

verbose.name: --verbose
verbose.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

no-interaction.name: --no-interaction
no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

process-isolation.name: --process-isolation
process-isolation.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

commands.name: generate:controller
commands.description: Generates a controller
commands.help:
The <info>generate:controller</info> command helps you generates new controllers
inside bundles.

By default, the command interacts with the developer to tweak the generation.
Any passed option will be used as a default value for the interaction
(<comment>--bundle</comment> and <comment>--controller</comment> are the only
ones needed if you follow the conventions):

<info>php app/console generate:controller --controller=AcmeBlogBundle:Post</info>

If you want to disable any user interaction, use <comment>--no-interaction</comment>
but don't forget to pass all needed options:

<info>php app/console generate:controller --controller=AcmeBlogBundle:Post --no-interaction</info>

Every generated file is based on a template. There are default templates but they can
be overriden by placing custom templates in one of the following locations, by order of priority:

<info>BUNDLE_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/controller
APP_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/controller</info>

You can check https://github.com/sensio/SensioGeneratorBundle/tree/master/Resources/skeleton
in order to know the file structure of the skeleton

controller.name: --controller
controller.description: The name of the controller to create

route-format.name: --route-format
route-format.description: The format that is used for the routing (yml, xml, php, annotation)

template-format.name: --template-format
template-format.description: The format that is used for templating (twig, php)

commands.name: init:acl
commands.description: Mounts ACL tables in the database
commands.help:
The <info>init:acl</info> command mounts ACL tables in the database.

<info>php /index.php init:acl</info>

The name of the DBAL connection must be configured in your <info>app/config/security.yml</info> configuration file in the <info>security.acl.connection</info> variable.

<info>security:
    acl:
        connection: default</info>

commands.name: router:debug
commands.description: Displays current routes for an application
commands.help:
The <info>router:debug</info> displays the configured routes:

  <info>php /index.php router:debug</info>

commands.name: router:dump-apache
commands.description: Dumps all routes as Apache rewrite rules
commands.help:
The <info>router:dump-apache</info> dumps all routes as Apache rewrite rules.
These can then be used with the ApacheUrlMatcher to use Apache for route
matching.

  <info>php /index.php router:dump-apache</info>

commands.name: router:match
commands.description: Helps debug routes by simulating a path info match
commands.help:
The <info>router:match</info> simulates a path info match:

  <info>php /index.php router:match /foo</info>

commands.name: server:run
commands.description: Runs PHP built-in web server
commands.help:
The <info>server:run</info> runs PHP built-in web server:

  <info>/index.php server:run</info>

To change default bind address and port use the <info>address</info> argument:

  <info>/index.php server:run 127.0.0.1:8080</info>

To change default docroot directory use the <info>--docroot</info> option:

  <info>/index.php server:run --docroot=htdocs/</info>

If you have custom docroot directory layout, you can specify your own
router script using <info>--router</info> option:

  <info>/index.php server:run --router=app/config/router.php</info>

Specifing a router script is required when the used environment is not "dev" or
"prod".

See also: http://www.php.net/manual/en/features.commandline.webserver.php

commands.name: swiftmailer:email:send
commands.description: Send simple email message
commands.help:
The <info>swiftmailer:email:send</info> command creates and send simple email message.

<info>php /index.php swiftmailer:email:send --mailer=custom_mailer --content-type=text/xml</info>

You can get body of message from file:
<info>php /index.php swiftmailer:email:send --body-source=file --body=/path/to/file</info>

commands.name: swiftmailer:spool:send
commands.description: Sends emails from the spool
commands.help:
The <info>swiftmailer:spool:send</info> command sends all emails from the spool.

<info>php app/console swiftmailer:spool:send --message-limit=10 --time-limit=10 --recover-timeout=900 --mailer=default</info>

time-limit.description: The time limit for sending messages (in seconds).

recover-timeout.description: The timeout for recovering messages that have taken too long to send (in seconds).

commands.name: translation:update
commands.description: Updates the translation file
commands.help:
The <info>translation:update</info> command extract translation strings from templates
of a given bundle. It can display them or merge the new ones into the translation files.
When new translation strings are found it can automatically add a prefix to the translation
message.

<info>php /index.php translation:update --dump-messages en AcmeBundle</info>
<info>php /index.php translation:update --force --prefix="new_" fr AcmeBundle</info>

bundle.name: bundle
bundle.description: The bundle where to load the messages

dump-messages.name: --dump-messages
dump-messages.description: Should the messages be dumped in the console

no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.

commands.name: twig:lint
commands.description: Lints a template and outputs encountered errors
commands.help:
The <info>twig:lint</info> command lints a template and outputs to stdout
the first encountered syntax error.

<info>php /index.php twig:lint filename</info>

The command gets the contents of <comment>filename</comment> and validates its syntax.

<info>php /index.php twig:lint dirname</info>

The command finds all twig templates in <comment>dirname</comment> and validates the syntax
of each Twig template.

<info>php /index.php twig:lint @AcmeMyBundle</info>

The command finds all twig templates in the <comment>AcmeMyBundle</comment> bundle and validates
the syntax of each Twig template.

<info>cat filename | php /index.php twig:lint</info>

The command gets the template contents from stdin and validates its syntax.

no-interaction.description: Do not ask any interactive question.
